data.title: Eye Filmmuseum
data.meta_description: The museum for film and the art of the moving image in The Netherlands. Visit the exhibition or cinema and discover our collection with more than 55.000 films.
data.text:
A Canterbury Tale

Much loved, daring classic is Powell’s eye catching, very personal journey through Kent, where three modern pilgrims have to solve a bizarre village crime.

A Matter of Life and Death

Crashed fighter pilot implores heaven to postpone his death. The reason: he has fallen in love with June. Romantic tale moves between monochrome and splendid Technicolor.

A New Kind of Wilderness

After a tragic event, a Norwegian family is forced to swap their wild existence in the forests for one in modern society. Best Documentary at Sundance.

A Serious Man

The Coen Brothers’ most personal film is a bitter-melancholy comedy about the meaninglessness of life and the trials and tribulations of a Jewish professor.

Akira

The compelling story of Japan's nuclear bomb trauma, the superb animation and the unique industrial soundtrack made this anime a classic.

Almost Famous

Very amusing coming-of-age story about a 15-year-old music journalist who joins an up-and-coming rock band on tour in the early 1970s.

Animal

Kalia, an entertainer at a second-rate beach hotel, finds it increasingly difficult to keep up the illusion of eternal youth. Rich, layered portrait of the Greek tourist industry.

Barton Fink

A playwright suffers writer’s block in Hollywood working on his script for a wrestling film. This brilliant black comedy morphs into a nightmarish take on the Dream Factory.

Baxter, Vera Baxter

Using minimal, yet highly effective, means Marguerite Duras paints a portrait of Vera Baxter (Claudine Gabay) as a bourgeois woman caught in the golden cage of marriage.

Binnenstebuiten 2

Inside Out 2 returns to Tiley’s brain now she has become a teenager right when the head office has to make room for new emotions.

Birdsong

Albert Serra tells the story of the Three Wise Men and baby Jesus with an epic, humorous undertone. The three of them set off: but in search of what, actually?

Black Narcissus

Steamy psychological portrait of five nuns who open a mission in the Himalayas and succumb to repressed erotic desires and madness.

Blood Simple

The feature film debut of the illustrious Coen brothers. A clumsy private eye does what he can to murder a two-timing wife (Francis McDormand). 4K restoration.

Bridge of Spies

Looking for great-sounding dialogue? The Coens can help – like they did on Spielberg’s solid Cold War film, with Tom Hanks playing a lawyer.

Brief History of a Family

Lin Jianjie’s intriguing debut. A brilliant student from a humble background inserts himself into a wealthy family whom he masterfully manipulates.

Bulworth

Sharp political comedy by and with Warren Beatty, bitingly satirising the American election circus as Senator Bulworth: a man who decides to speak straight from the heart.

Cameraman: The Life and Work of Jack Cardiff

Jack Cardiff, ‘the master of Technicolor’ was the cameraman for films including The Red Shoes and Black Narcissus. This documentary unravels Cardiff’s importance to the duo of Powell & Pressburger.

Christmas in July

People convince office clerk Jimmy that he has won 25,000 dollar in a competition. Preston Sturges’ hilarious, razor sharp satire on the American obsession with success.

Ciske de Rat

Box-office hit about a well-meaning street urchin who is sent to the reformatory, with lead roles for Danny de Munck and Amsterdam in the 1930s.

Ciske de Rat

Box-office hit about a well-meaning street urchin who is sent to the reformatory, with lead roles for Danny de Munck and Amsterdam in the 1930s.

City of Wind

Sensuous, beautifully filmed debut telling the story of a teenager in Mongolia navigating between his own desires and his duties as a spiritual shaman.

Crime and Punishment

A police station on the Chinese-North Korean border: trainee officers brutally maintain order, almost to an absurd degree. Revealing portrait by documentary maker Zhao Liang.

Crimewave

Sam Raimi asked Joel and Ethan Coen to co-author the script for this deliciously unusual mix of comedy, film noir and an homage to B movies.

Crossing Istanbul

The search for her long lost niece takes Lia from Georgia to Istanbul. Loving road movie about being queer and trans acceptance.

Cutter's Way

John Heard and Jef Bridges are the antiheroes of this neo-noir about the murder of a call girl in post-Vietnam America. Ivan Passer’s thriller went on to become a rarely seen cult film

Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed

The oldest surviving feature-length animated film and one of the few surviving early films made by a woman, with music by Steven Kamperman.

Die Perücke

Fantastical, expressionist drama from 1924 about a poor, bald man who, when he puts on a wig, is transformed into an 18-century prince. Live piano music: Martin de Ruiter.

Dikkie Dik en de verdwenen knuffel

Tummy Tom makes his debut in a lead role in this do-and-sing-along animated film. Help Tummy Tom search for his favourite cuddly toy.

Drive-Away Dolls

Ethan Coen’s first feature film without brother Joel is described by the maker as a 'B film comedy about two lesbians in a road movie', and is the first in a trilogy of queer B films.

Electra Glide in Blue

Ambitious motorcycle cop John Wintergreen becomes a detective, and decides to do something to stop the rot within the police service. Incisive portrait of the deplorable state of the US in the early ’70s.

Emilia Pérez

Jacques Audiard (Dheepan) intrepidly and with flair takes on the musical comedy genre, setting his film in the worlds of Mexican drugs cartels and gender transition.

Eureka

The native inhabitants of a Brazilian rainforest are not much better off than those of a Native American reservation in this magical realist film, with a stunning role for a stork.

Explanation for Everything

In Hungary, political polarisation can have drastic consequences. Gábor Reisz makes this palpable through the conflict between high-school student Abel and his parents, and history teacher Jakab.

Fargo

Jet-black comedy parodies the true crime genre and is intensely thrilling thanks to its hilarious, over the top ordinariness. Watch out for the wood chipper!

Film as a Subversive Art

Amos Vogel’s influential book Film as A Subversive Art (1974) was hugely important to Catalan director Albert Serra. With short films and a lecture by Eye programmer Thijs Havens.

Filmmagie: Dieren

Discover the magic of film through five short animated films with animals in the lead roles. Afterwards, you can make your own flip book (from 6 years).

Firebrand

Katherine Parr, the wife of tyrannical King Henry VIII (Jude Law), has to fight for her life. Contemporary, feminist take on Tudor era palace intrigue.

Freek de Jonge 80 jaar: Het kistje

Freek de Jonge turns 80 today, and we’re celebrating with the première of the animated film Het kistje, with Freek and Hella de Jonge attending.

Fremont

Jalali’s fourth feature is a drily ironic, poignant portrait in black and white of Afghan refugee and former interpreter Donya. On displacement and the search for happiness.

Go Go Tales

Chosen by Albert Serra, made by diehard independent maker Abel Ferrara: on the downfall of debt-ridden Ray Ruby, a strip club owner with a heart of gold.

Gone to Earth

The story is simple – two men fighting over a woman – but this version by famous duo Powell & Pressburger is a mysterious, fascinating Technicolor melodrama.

Hail, Caesar!

This eccentric satire on nineteen-fifties Hollywood centres on a studio fixer who has to bend over backwards to try and solve the studio’s problems. With George Clooney.

Hockney: I Love View

Road trip to visit world-famous painter David Hockney in Normandy, where artist Pieter Athmer hopes to meet him by means of a surprise.

I Know Where I'm Going

On her way to her fiancé a headstrong young woman is stuck in a Scottish coastal town for a week, where she falls for an affable seaman.

I've Always Loved You

Romance, drama and runaway emotion: everything in Frank Borzage’s classic about the unrequited love of a pianist for her maestro is Technicolor over-the-top.

Il bidone

Dark, neo-realistic and mildly comedic crime drama about a lonely fraudster forced to witness the consequences of his misdeeds. One of Ethan Coen’s favourites.

Il pleut dans la maison

Surprisingly tender coming-of-age drama about 17-year-old Purdey and her brother, left to fend for themselves during a hot, stormy summer at a tourist lake.

Inside Llewyn Davis

The Coen Brothers created another wonderfully eccentric character in the shape of the wandering, failed folk singer Llewyn Davis complete with tragicomic dialogues and a touch of the surreal.

Inside Out 2

Inside Out 2 returns to Riley’s brain now she has become a teenager right when the head office has to make room for new emotions.

Inside the Yellow Cocoon Shell

Thiện’s return to the countryside where he grew up turns out to be the beginning of a spiritual journey of (self-)discovery. Slow cinema in its most daring, radical form.

International Talk Like a Pirate Day Night

Aaarrr! Pirates, mutineers and buccaneers, pin back your ears: on International Talk Like a Pirate Day we’re showing an hour of clips from pirate films, followed by John Carpenter’s The Fog.

Kinds of Kindness

During the post-production of Poor Things, Yorgos Lanthimos’ also shot his tryptic about human relations gone awry featuring Willem Dafoe and Emma Stone.

L'Atlantide

Heroic and spectacular desert fantasy shot in the Sahara in which two French legionairs end up in the lost kingdom of Atlantis. Live musical accompaniment by Marmoucha Orchestra.

La battaglia di Algeri

Dramatic thriller based on actual events about the clashes between Algerian rebels and French security forces during the Algerian War of Independence in the late 1950s.

La piscine

Sultry summer classic in the form of a psychological thriller centred around a swimming pool. Starring Romy Schneider, Alain Delon and Jane Birkin, directed by Jacques Deray. 4K restoration.

La prima notte di quiete

Alain Delon is a jaded, tormented literature teacher in wintry Rimini; director Valerio Zurlini cast 37-year-old Delon in an atypical role – he tackles it with verve.

Langue étrangère

Coming-of-age story about Fanny and Lena, two 17-year-old school students who take part in an exchange programme. They get to know one another in Leipzig and Strasbourg, and soon become inseparable.

Le gang des Bois du Temple

A robbery on the periphery of Paris leads to tragedy in this film in which reality gives the lie to the dream of a better life.

Le procès Goldman

This tautly directed film about the notorious trial of French revolutionary and robber Pierre Goldman in 1976 examines more than simply the question of guilt.

Liberté

Just how liberating is it to impose no boundaries on freedom? The libertine aristocrats in Albert Serra’s ninth feature film strive to answer this question.

Lola rennt

Two lovers have just twenty minutes to change the course of their lives in Tykwer’s scintillating, unpredictable hit film – with a lead role for Berlin.

Los reyes del mundo

Five Colombian teenagers want to start a new life, away from the violence they grew up with. Dreamy, surreal images of this country in transition.

Mal Viver

In the first part of an oppressive two-parter set in the same hotel, three generations of mothers and daughters drive one another to distraction.

Medea, Opera & Film

An evening dedicated to the cross-pollination between opera and film, focusing on Pasolini's Medea (1969) and opera director Sjaron Minailo on Medea, his favourite opera.

No Country for Old Men

The Coen Brothers’ deconstruction of the western won a total of four Oscars. A Texan redneck, a psychopathic killer and an old, wise sheriff pursue one another.

Nomadland

Frances McDormand is impressive as Fern, who – in her 60s – sets out across the American west in search of work and company.

One-Eyed Jacks

Psychological western in which outlaw Marlon Brando takes revenge on his former partner in crime (Karl Malden), who has gone on to become a sheriff.

Ouwehoeren

Twin sisters Louise and Martine have been familiar faces in Amsterdam’s redlight district for almost 50 years. Candid documentary about the fun and secrets of the prostitution trade. In memory of Rob Schröder.

Raging Bull

You might not think it, but for Jake La Motta’s sequences in Raging Bull Martin Scorsese was inspired by the choreography in The Red Shoes by filmmaking duo Powell & Pressburger.

Raising Arizona

According to may, the best comedy ever about a coupler who can’t have children (Nicolas Cage and Holly Hunter) who kidnap a baby and are hunted by a furniture magnate.

Red Tail

A mysterious red tail leads viewers on a magical VR journey, creating a poetic metaphor of people’s childhood memories.

Romance de Valentía

Sonia Herman Dolz (Yo soy así) follows toreador Enrique Ponce in a partly dramatized documentary that unfolds through visual association.

Salesman

Lively portrait of four Bible salesmen, and of 1960s America – Christianity and consumerism, interwoven with a sales pitch that’s steadily losing its appeal.

Samsara

A dystopian trip through time and space over millions of years, inspired by the Buddhist principle of the six realms.

Schirkoa

Rumours of a fabled land of freedom cause chaos in an overregulated society in this cool, noir-like animation.

Showing Up

Michelle Williams keeps her acting affectingly small as artist Lizzy, who struggles to find a balance between her passion and everyday obligations.

Sneak Preview: Albert Serra & Chris Dercon

An exclusive screening of Albert Serra's latest film. The screening precedes a conversation between Albert Serra and Chris Dercon, director of the Fondation Cartier, Paris.

Spoof Night

Martin Koolhoven and Ronald Simons take us on a trip through famous film satires such as This Is Spinal Tap and Flying High; the brilliant parody Young Frankenstein is the main feature.

Spoorloos

George Sluizer’s Golden Calf-winning psychological thriller about a disappearance – based on the novel by Tim Krabbé – went on to become a classic. Starring Johanna ter Steege and Gene Bervoets.

Sterben

Challenging portrait of parents and adult children reunited by the vicissitudes of fate, with an at times darkly humorous tone. Winner of a Silver Bear, Berlinale 2024.

Story of My Death

‘Casanova meets Dracula’ could be the summary of Albert Serra’s film about the wondrous meeting of a light-footed hedonist and a bloodthirsty romantic in the Carpathians.

Tatami

Political thriller surrounding a top Iranian judo competitor who is to face an Israeli opponent at the World Championships. Directed by Israeli/Iranian duo Guy Nattiv and Zar Amir Ebrahimi.

The Age of Innocence

Scorsese is an admirer of Powell & Pressburger’s work, in which suppressed passion plays an important role – as it does in The Age of Innocence.

The Bad News Bears

Hilarious sports comedy about a lower-league baseball team that hopes that a new beer-swilling coach can turn their fortunes around. A Favourite of Ethan Coen.

The Big Lebowski

Jeff Bridges, John Turturro, Steve Buscemi and John Goodman shine as ‘the laziest man in L.A. County’ and his bowling buddies, with a stunning guest appearance by a rug.

The Edge of the World

The moving story of a remote Scottish island and its inhabitants, whose way of life is threatened by the rapidly industrialising world.

The Hudsucker Proxy

Wildly styled homage to the screwball comedy in which the naive Barnes (Tim Robbins) is suddenly put in charge of the mighty Hudsucker Industries.

The Ladykillers (2004)

In this remake of the Ealing Studios comedy from 1955, a self-deprecatory Tom Hanks plays a clumsy robber facing a whip-smart landlady.

The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp

In 1943, Winston Churchill was 'not amused' by this British army satire. The classic follows a general’s career until the dark days of World War II.

The Lord Worked Wonders in Me

A ‘making of’ a film that was never made – this is the absurd twist Albert Serra came up with for his road movie about the place where the Don Quixote story is set.

The Man Who Wasn't There

Wonderful homage to film noir is a stylistic tour de force full of adultery, blackmail and murder in which a lethargic hairdresser tries to escape his pointless life.

The Names of Christ

Albert Serra’s TV series is a biting satire on the art world and a layered, conceptual reflection on the relationship between museums/visitors and artworks/exhibition spaces.

The Red Shoes

Flamboyant Technicolor adaptation of Hans Christian Andersen’s fairy tale, a story about a ballerina set against the backdrop of Diaghilev’s celebrated Ballets Russes.

The Small Back Room

A dark trip through the psyche of an alcoholic: with tension, romance and a famous expressionistic scene featuring a gigantic whisky bottle.

The Souvenir

Filmmaker Joanna Hogg likes to be inspired by renowned film duo Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, in whose films love can be a destructive force.

The Spy in Black

In this accomplished thriller bursting with tension, depth and flair, a U-boat captain (Conrad Veidt) arrives on the Orkney Islands during World War I to meet a fellow spy.

The Substance

Demi Moore stars as the presenter of a fitness show in this sardonic, witty body horror about miracle cure ‘The Substance’, which is supposed to combat ageing.

The Tales of Hoffmann

Stunning marriage of cinema and opera about the three great loves of a young poet, and a phantasmagorical trip into a world of sensual pleasures and decadence.

The Tenant

Unforgettable: Polanski as the tenant of a Paris apartment where the previous tenant committed suicide. A favourite of Joel and Ethan Coen.

The Third Man

Post-war Vienna is a hornet’s nest of black marketeers and espionage. The exemplary noir classic, starring Orson Welles and Joseph Cotton, now in a 4K restoration.

The Wizard of Oz

Classic musical about Dorothy (Judy Garland), who like a kind of Alice in Wonderland is transported to Oz, where she experiences all sorts of wondrous adventures.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri

Darkly-comedic drama in which a mother makes accusations about the unsolved murder of her daughter using billboards. Oscars for Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell.

Trailblazing Taiwan 360°

Discover Taiwan’s groundbreaking innovation and creativity through five exceptional Virtual Reality films. Taiwan is a trailblazer in the VR industry.

True Grit

Impressive remake of a John Wayne western is a all-too-human tale of revenge involving a smart girl who engages a tough Marshall Jeff Bridges.

Tummy Tom and the Lost Teddybear

Tummy Tom makes his debut in a lead role in this do-and-sing-along animated film. Help Tummy Tom search for his favourite cuddly toy.

Vampyr

Surreal vampire film. The four cellists of Metrocelli and bandoneonist Martin de Ruiter capture the eerie atmosphere of Dreyer's images in a mesmerizing score.

Viver Mal

In Mal Viver, the hotel guests remained in the background; in its counterpart, Viver Mal, they are the ones dissected by director Canijo’s scalpel.

Yannick

Hilarious satire by master absurdist Quentin Dupieux about someone in a theatre audience who is so incensed by the production that he decides to re-write it himself. Screening accompanies Daaaaaalí.
